review.title: Coactive Critiquing: Elicitation of Preferences and Features
review.abstract: When faced with complex choices, users refine their own preference criteria as they explore the catalogue of options. In this paper we propose an approach to preference elicitation suited for this scenario. We extend Coactive Learning, which iteratively collects manipulative feedback, to optionally query example critiques. User critiques are integrated into the learning model by dynamically extending the feature space. Our formulation natively supports constructive learning tasks, where the option catalogue is generated on-the-fly. We present an upper bound on the average regret suffered by the learner. Our empirical analysis highlights the promise of our approach.

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text: In contrast to coactive learning, the feature space is obtained dynamically through interaction with the user. We discussed the theoretical guarantees of the method and a heuristic query selection strategy that balances the effort of the user with the expressivity of the acquired feature space. We presented experimental evidence to support our results. Coactive critiquing competes with better informed baselines and often requires far fewer features to obtain comparable (or better) recommendations. As with conversation recommendations, coactive critiquing could in principle deal with text or speech crises in free form, see for example Grasch, Felfernig and Reinfrank (2013). Coactive critiquing is particularly suitable for constructive preference elimination tasks (Teso, Passerini and Viappiani 2016).
